bestBHT.bht: The concept of judges as representatives of God is emphasized, drawing from the wider interpretation of the law in the Old Testament. Jesus challenges the rabbis by referencing the Psalm that rebukes unjust judges and calls them gods. By appealing to scripture, Jesus defends his identity and asserts the elevated status of judges as God's representatives. He highlights the significance of justice and righteousness in their roles, addressing their accusations through the authority of the written word.

Henry Alford: The word law here is in its widest acceptation,—the whole Old Testament..."
The Psalm is directed against the injustice and tyranny of judges..."
And in the Psalm reference is made by 'I have said' to previous places of Scripture where judges are so called...
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 34-36. Is it not written in your
official representatives and commissioned agents of
Marvin Vincent: Is it not written [ουκ εστιν γεγραμμενον] . More strictly, does it not stand written."
Law [νομω] . The word is sometimes used in the New Testament of other scriptures.
I said, etc. The reference is to Psalms 82:6.
John Calvin: He clears himself of the crime charged against him, not by denying that he is the Son of God, but by maintaining that he had justly said so.
The argument which he employs is not drawn from equals, but from the less to the greater.
Christ applies this to the case in hand, that they receive the name of gods, because they are God’s ministers for governing the world.
Philip Schaff: The psalm is a reproof of unrighteous judges.
In any case the pronoun 'I' is strongly marked, I myself, who utter the rebuke and had foretold the punishment, had borne witness to the dignity of the position of the judge.
The meaning will either be that the law 'called,' or the speaker implied in the emphatic 'I,' viz. the psalmist writing under inspiration from God and expressing His mind.
Archibald T. Robertson: The judges of Israel abused their office and God is represented in Psalms 82:6 as calling them 'gods' because they were God's representatives.
Jesus meets the rabbis on their own ground in a thoroughly Jewish way.
John Gill: The law includes not only the Pentateuch, but all the books of the Old Testament.
Magistrates are called gods, when the sense is only, that they are like to the angels in respect of their souls.
Judges are called gods when they judge truly and aright.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse addresses the concept of judges as representatives of God, drawing from the wider interpretation of the word law in the Old Testament. The Psalm mentioned in the commentary specifically critiques unjust judges and refers to previous scriptures where they are called gods. Jesus engages the rabbis on their own terms, using the authority of the written word to challenge their accusations. The argument here is not about equality, but about recognizing the elevated status of judges as God's agents in the world. By appealing to the scriptures, Jesus not only defends himself but also underscores the importance of upholding justice and righteousness in their positions of authority.

The concept of judges as representatives of God is emphasized, drawing from the wider interpretation of the law in the Old Testament. The Psalm mentioned critiques unjust judges and refers to previous scriptures where they are called gods. Jesus engages the rabbis on their own terms, using the authority of the written word to challenge their accusations. The argument is about recognizing the elevated status of judges as God's agents in the world. By appealing to the scriptures, Jesus defends himself and emphasizes the importance of justice in their positions of authority.

The verse highlights the broader understanding of the law in the Old Testament, encompassing the entire Old Testament. The Psalm referenced criticizes unjust judges and considers them as representatives of God. Jesus confronts the rabbis on their own terms, using the written word to counter their claims. He defends himself by acknowledging the elevated status of judges as God's appointed agents. Jesus emphasizes the significance of upholding justice and righteousness in their roles, appealing to scriptural authority to support his argument.

The concept of judges as representatives of God is emphasized, drawing from the wider interpretation of the law in the Old Testament. Jesus challenges the rabbis by referencing the Psalm that rebukes unjust judges and calls them gods. By appealing to scripture, Jesus defends his identity and asserts the elevated status of judges as God's representatives. He highlights the significance of justice and righteousness in their roles, addressing their accusations through the authority of the written word.

Jesus engages the rabbis on their own terms by appealing to the Old Testament Scriptures, specifically referencing the Psalm that condemns unjust judges and calls them gods. He defends his own identity and asserts that judges, as representatives of God, hold an elevated status. By challenging his accusers through the authority of the written word, Jesus emphasizes the importance of justice and righteousness in their roles. The broader understanding of the law in the Old Testament is brought into focus, encompassing the entire Scripture.
